explanation:
Why each symbol is needed for MISRA C (string-bounds) analysis:

- strcmp
  - The target function calls strcmp(method, "GET"). To decide if this use can access out-of-bounds memory we must know the exact semantics and preconditions of strcmp (it requires both pointers to be non-NULL and point to NUL-terminated character arrays). Include the strcmp symbol/prototype/contract so the analyzer can verify those requirements are met at the call site.

- MHD_AccessHandlerCallback
  - ahc_echo implements the libmicrohttpd access-handler signature. The important piece for strcmp safety is the contract provided by the code that invokes this callback: specifically whether the 'method' parameter is guaranteed to be non-NULL and NUL-terminated. The MHD_AccessHandlerCallback type / caller contract (the library function that invokes the callback) is required to establish those guarantees.

- simple_response_text
  - The function uses sizeof(simple_response_text)/sizeof(char) - 1 to compute response_size and passes simple_response_text through callback_param->response_data. If any string functions (strlen, strcpy, etc.) are later applied to this buffer by the callback or other code, we must know the definition (array vs pointer, actual length, embedded NULs) to ensure such calls cannot read/write beyond its bounds.

- callback
  - The user-supplied callback (passed to MHD_create_response_from_callback) will be invoked later with response_data. If that callback uses any <string.h> functions (strlen, memcpy, strcpy, etc.) on response_data, we must inspect its code to ensure it only accesses within the bounds established by response_size. Include the callback symbol/definition so the analyzer can check its uses of string functions against response_size/simple_response_text.

- free_callback_param
  - Provided to MHD_create_response_from_callback and closely associated with lifecycle of callback_param->response_data. While not directly a string function, its definition helps reason about ownership and lifetime of the buffer passed into other code that might call string functions; include it to ensure no use-after-free that could create apparent out-of-bounds accesses.

- MHD_create_response_from_callback
  - The behavior of this API (how/when it invokes the callback, whether it expects NUL-terminated buffers, whether it copies or references the provided data) affects whether subsequent string-function calls on the data are safe. Include its prototype/semantics so the analyzer can determine if/how the library will call back and whether the passed pointers/sizes are honored.

- MHD_add_response_header
  - ahc_echo calls MHD_add_response_header(response, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_TRANSFER_ENCODING, "chunked"). MHD_add_response_header may internally use string.h functions (strdup/strlen/strcmp). To ensure there is no out-of-bounds use of strings that originate in ahc_echo (header name/value), the analyzer needs the API/implementation contract for this function (does it expect NUL-terminated strings, does it copy or reference them, etc.).

Note: The above symbols let the next analyst confirm that every string.h call that either appears directly in ahc_echo (strcmp) or that may be invoked later on pointers supplied by ahc_echo (callback, library functions) receives valid, NUL-terminated buffers of appropriate size and lifetime. If those contracts guarantee non-NULL, NUL-terminated inputs and correct size/ownership, the strcmp call and subsequent string operations can be judged MISRA-compliant; otherwise the analyzer must flag potential violations.
